subtitle.Text: It’s one of those things where we had always wanted to,
well a) we wanted to pay off Sam’s darkroom by letting you go in it and see photos that she had taken,
and b) this started from a point of me just being like, oh we’ll just end the game the same way we ended Minerva’s Den, it’ll be fine,
but between those two things we initially figured we were signing up for photos that would’ve taken a lot of time and effort to make, of like,
a photo strip of the two of them in a photo booth which would mean like, let’s do four pairs of you know, photo painted photos of these characters-
Steve: And you know, just like pictures of them in the mirror together and all of this very high cost facial rendering, basically, for Karla to do,
because we had this style that was like okay, you do photo collage and then you paint it over to make it look consistent
and it’s a lot of work and it’s hard to get the pieces and the lighting and the poses and everything looking right.
Karla: I’m just not that much of a pro in order to be able to do it that fast, and so, yeah it would’ve been months.
Steve: So we have the one very close up photo of Lonnie’s eye and then we just brainstormed what are evocative images of the two of them
and their life that we could create without having to show their faces a bunch.

And I think that, like so many things, taking a step back and only seeing the implication of these characters is probably a lot more powerful than if we had just made a bunch of pictures of them looking at the camera.
Karla: Being less literal is definitely more meaningful in this particular case, to the extent that I remember when I took these holding hands photos with Rachel-
I don’t know, I took, twenty, a dozen, something like that, different versions of them and then I was going through them afterward
to try and find the one that I wanted to use to Photoshop and add letters on the heart and everything,
and I found myself thinking, aw these are all so sweet, and like, I had just taken them ten minutes ago with my roommate
and it was just like, somehow this here is more evocative and meaningful than a happy face, I guess.
But anyways, yeah, I was fooled by my own schtick which is extremely silly.
